On february 10, 2014
Pyrrhus

A2b Do you remember the exact details of the disease?
If it, y'know, says it causes extra (or unmissable) damage, then yes it can cause a death. In which case (unless you're maybe spading for the sake of Symptoms or forget) it could be considered suicide.

But, it sounds like it only gives a Symptom not a discrete description of the effects, so I'd surmise that symptom just gives you losses to AP/MP if you hug it or are in the room, but that's just a suspicion.

Tl;dr If it discretely says that you lose extra health/instantly die, or you know the effects of the symptom it has (if it has one), then yes.
Also, it's not comparable with the Open Air Brain injury, which is a bug, unless the Cat Allergy actually says that it kills you when you hug the cat but doesn't, in which case it is ALSO a bug.

On february 10, 2014
[7897795]

Q4: What does 'spading' mean?
On february 10, 2014
Pyrrhus

A4 'Spading' is the meta-activity of testing a function to see the outcome, the difference between it and regular investigation/testing is that Spading is for investigation of the RNG and is done lots of times to ascertain the likely chances of the outcomes.

Q7 Can you graft decomposed fruits or it will kill your original plant?
On february 10, 2014
Pyrrhus
Ef_leftOh wow, this QA really works like a charm, thank you! Then one more please:
Q7 Can you graft decomposed fruits or it will kill your original plant?

A8
Yes you can graft (as well as plant) spoilt fruit without it killing the plant. Grafting really is more like planting a fruit without having to go through the motions of killing the old one. The plant will die if you're dirty, it's diseased, or is thirsty/dried out though.

Total for mush is reported to be 3104 experience. 16 * 505 + 10 * 500 + 3104 = 16184 total experience is required for 100% accomplishment. Q21a Yes, it is indeed the progress towards having ALL of the skills.
Q21b You're missing the 80xp from your first purchase of gold days, which brings the total to 16104 XP.
16104/[2xp per cycle*8 cycles a day] = 1006.5 days. That's 2 years, 276 days, and 15 hours, which with the highest value pack of Gold days (5*200 for 59.99 Euros each) plus a one month pack for 9.99 Euros each gives 309.94 Euros in total. Expensive habit!
(This doesn't add in possible XP gains from say, the SNC Kitchen, a gold project)
Q21c Assumedly not; it looks like the only XP reset was when the game crossed over from the Beta (where there was 6xp a cycle) to the full version as we know it now.

N_Faker
PyrrhusA15 By unstable I think you mean unperishable. Also no, Rations and Coffee do not spoil so do not cause illness unless those Rations were made from spoiled Alien Steaks. When made into Rations they will still have a 50% chance of giving food poisoning.

Coffee spoils. Only things that don't spoil are drugs(anabolics not included) and uncooked rations. Consumables bought from the Vending Machine don't spoil either.

Coffee from the Thermos starts to spoil only after you take them out.

On february 12, 2014
deviking

A 24 a punch will make the victim take more damage so that you get more pieces of information out every health gone is 1 action and torturer does 1 on its own then a punch with wrestler adds a bit extra makes it more useful basically
On february 12, 2014
Pyrrhus

A23 extended Control + enter to add a new line at the end of the message. E.g. if you press control +enter when you're on a line that already has text on, you just skip to a new, empty line at the end of the message.
Empty linebreaks between full ones connect the two lines that have text on them, e.g.;

BlahBlahBlah.
<Empty Line>
RahRahRah.

comes out as;

BlahBlahBlah.RahRahRah.
Empty lines can be achieved by putting a single space in the new line, however.
On february 12, 2014

[Assigning correct answer numbers to questions]
agewisdom
Q36: On an expedition to a planet with a volcano but no O2. There are 3 expedition members with space suits and one without a space suit. The one without space suit will stay on the Icarus Bay. In the event there is a group death due to the volcano exploding, what is the outcome?

a) everyone dies?
b) the crew without the space suit on the Icarus will survive safely and pilot the ship back to the Daedalus

If (b), then
(i) will the last crew member get all the goodies from the expo just prior to the volcano wipe, i.e. artifacts, fuel, fruits etc.
(ii) will the last crew member get back all the tools carried by the other 3 expo members, like drill, space suits etc.
A37 The person who doesn't have a spacesuit doesn't stay in the Icarus bay, they go in the ship. They just don't go on the expedition and are not as being on it. So yes they'll pilot it back.
i) Yes, they'll bring all the goodies.
ii) No, the tools carried by the other 3 are lost forever. Big loss for some minor goodies.


Slider2kQ37 Will gains from Botanist or Survivalist skills on expeditions be increased accordingly if more than one member have the skill?

A38 Yes, for both.

Q43: What do post its do exactly? Someone said they are needed on expeditions, there is also that "access terminal" button on some of them when you click the note, what does it do

On february 14, 2014
Secondary

A43 access terminal is for the block of post its, when you click it you can write something on an post it and you will get an post it with your writing on it. Post its make it less likely for you to lose other good items on expos where you can lose things, so you should drop talkies and trackers and unnecesesary items and fill rest of inventory with the post its.
On february 14, 2014
[7950824]

A43 You use the block of postits to write individual postits (using the access terminal option), which become separate items, in your inventory if there's room or dropped into the room if your inventory is full. So you can use them to write notes, which can be a life saver for you if you become injured in a way that prevents speech, and they can be a 'useless item'. When you go on expos to certain zones, like strong winds or Intelligent life, there's a chance that an item will be lost forever. Those are the expos you want to take postits on - not the block, but individual notes someone made. That way there's a chance that the useless postit will be lost and not something you hope to use in future expos. Just don't take the block down with you, only the written notes.

Pyrrhus

A44 Not the block but individual post-it's yes; the chance of losing any specific item is assumedly 1 in (number of items held by whole crew). By having empty spaces, you increase chances to lose equipment and by having multiple post its stuffed in your inventory you increase the chance that if you lose an item, it is one of the post its.

Cimanyd
goatQ44 ^does simply holding it reduce chance of losing things?
thanks for such fast reply :-)

A44
It doesn't change the chance of losing a thing but the lost thing could be a post-it, and losing one of them isn't a problem compared to important things.

If you're carrying a drill on a one man expedition (not that that would normally happen) and you lose an item with Strong Winds, it will be the drill, which is bad for the ship to lose.

If you're carrying a drill and two post-its, you only have a 1 in 3 chance to lose anything useful.

[6826491]

Just in case it still hasn't been made clear:

Killing Chun as a human player is sanctionable, because it's griefing the human team. She can't be Mush, she can't be spored, and is immune to Transfer. She is the only player the human team can be sure isn't Mush, and her first skill reduces the daily morale loss of the human team. Because of this, the only acceptable circumstance under which a human player can kill Chun, is if there is clear evidence that the Chun player is griefing the ship. In this sole instance, killing the Chun player may be considered acceptable if reported. However, the loss of Chun can doom a ship, so killing her is also to be regarded as a last resort.

So in case people may ask: Yes, you CAN use a single attack to kick an inactive Chun player out of a bed, just like anyone else. Make sure you're not using a weapon when you do, because a critical hit will kill her instantly. If you kill her, you may be reported for it.

Q48: If you heal a mush with the serum and there is still a mush left, is he allowed to say his name?
On february 14, 2014
[6826491]

A48: There's been some debate over this in the SDF, and the consensus we came to is this: The newly cured human CAN reveal who the other Mush are, and there are no rules being broken if they do reveal any other Mush. But they also aren't forced to do so by the rules.

There's an argument to be made about RP under those circumstances, and that's being taken into account here. It's up to the individual player to decide if they're going to reveal if there are other Mush, or to confirm that there are no other Mush. They can also choose to claim they don't remember, if they want to use that RP route.

However... That doesn't stop the other human players from killing the cured human, if that player refuses to name the other Mush. It's a very risky way to RP, obviously, but either choice (to reveal or not) conforms to the rules. And likewise, if the crew kills a player because they refused to reveal the Mush after being cured, that probably won't be sanctioned, either.

In short:

Can they reveal the other Mush? Yes, but they can also choose not to, and both options are valid.
Can you kill them for not revealing the other Mush? Yes, but you don't have to kill them if they refuse. (Consider that by curing them, you've regained an active player, in most circumstances...one who is now confirmed to be human. It would be a shame to have wasted the AP on the Serum, then choose to kill the person you just managed to save.)

[6826491]

A48 Addendum: Speaking for myself here, if I were a cured Mush, I would reveal if any Mush remain alive. That's just how I would play it out. But there was also a compelling argument to be made that revealing the other Mush can spoil the fun of the hunt. Of the two options, I'd say the majority of the playerbase would reveal the other Mush, and without too much hesitation. But then I don't tend to RP, at least not in games of this nature.

I find the compelling part of the RP argument is that it can end the Mush hunt instantly, and take some of the challenge out of the game. Now, that's not to suggest that finishing the serum is an easy task; it requires a dead Mush, plus quite a bit of AP, unless Genius is used... But if the cured person works for the human team in every aspect other than revealing the Mush (claiming temporary amnesia, for example) then are they really playing against their team? I'm having to play Devil's advocate on this, because I know what I would do if I were cured. But I can also see how the thrill of the hunt is ruined by suddenly knowing who the Mush are.

That is why there's some gray area to this issue. Yes, they can choose to not reveal if there other Mush. And their crew may kill them for that RP decision. But unless the cured player were taking directly harmful actions (say, attacking human players without sufficient evidence) then sanctioning makes less sense.

[6826491]
ZaphodBeeblbroxSo, bringing this question to the mods...

First off, going on strike isn't a viable option. You could still be sanctioned if you quit playing partway through the game, if it is reported. In the case you described, stating the refusal of any Mush testing at the beginning is a good thing to do, but quitting mid-game still breaks the rule about seeing the game to its conclusion. In other words, two wrongs still don't make a right.

You should definitely make your case about how wasteful blanket tests are, and specifically state that if someone is killed just because they refused to be tested, their killer(s) may be reported and sanctioned. If that still doesn't dissuade people from insisting on blanket testing, feel free to point them to this post. I don't think you can argue against Chao, though. His use of Torture may be a forced "test", but if it's used correctly, it's a scalpel, not a bludgeon.

Regarding Chao, he could still use Torture, with (or without) cause, though it goes without saying that it ideally should be used sparingly, to confirm existing suspicions about a suspected Mush, rather than be used to blanket test everyone in a wasteful manner...and you know that I am fervently against blanket testing. It also goes without saying that Chao players who indiscriminately use Torture often end up being killed for it... When I play Chao, I always announce that while I will use Torture without immediate warning, I won't use it indiscriminately, and I will always explain the reason(s) for my suspicion after the fact. To that end, I don't consider the use of Torture in that specific manner to fall under the same category as blanket food tests, shower tests, etc. If it's only being used to confirm existing suspicions, and not in lieu of investigation, it's fair game.

I don't think a viable argument can be made to forbid voluntary "testing", either. If someone wants to consume two items in a cycle, AND then uses that AP to immediately help the ship, it's fair game. The same applies for Vending Machine consumables; if someone wants to spend their Klix in that way, it's their right. They might use it to buy coffee for Gioele, for example, and potentially prove two people to be human in the process. While yes, it reduces the chances of certain players being investigated...I've also stated more than once that people who have been confirmed as human can make for excellent conversion or Transfer targets. Just bear that in mind.

Confirming what npfan stated, if there is good reason to suspect you of being a Mush, other than the refusal to take a test, they can still kill you and not be sanctioned for it. If there is a blanket test being pushed, and you get killed only because you refused to participate, sanctions may be involved for your killers. It's a very thin line, though.

nuctu While it's not strictly forbidden to talk about the details of ships in progress, it is discouraged. [6826491]

A81 update: True, you can't do anything with pills, but fruit and coffee can be frozen and then hyperdefrosted in order to kill any spores on them. The problem is, you need the Microwave for the defrosting process; the kitchen is insufficient. Also, consuming frozen fruit or coffee COSTS one AP, as well as one morale. This makes freezing impractical, but occasionally necessary.

So back to the theoretical question: The first one you pick up will be infected. you could pick up a second ration, and (probably) be safe when you eat the second one..unless multiple items in that stack are spored.

[6826491]
ZaphodBeeblbroxQ91: What's the mods situation on a crewmember that doesn't communicate, and does not follow the crew main projects... i.e.: instead of working on (useful) project A (probably because doesn't read the comms channel), works on (useless) project B. Disregarding any words from several crewmembers trying to get said person to work on the selected project (project A).
Would it be admited to kill said person? Or that would be sanctionable? Of course, since one can be sanctioned if reported... I doubt anyone in the crew will report the killer, but I'd like to know what's the opinion of the mods.

A91: They could be new, and might not even have their WT. Or they might be new and not be paying any attention to chat. It's also possible that they're Mush, and they're intentionally doing those things. Without having access to the logs, it's difficult to tell. It's not unheard of to kill players who act in this manner...however, you might want to cover your bases before you kill them. It will greatly reduce the chances of you being sanctioned, even if you are reported.

If you make the case to the rest of the crew that the player in question is either a Mush or griefing (if not a newbie, and causing harm unintentionally...) Chances are you'll be able to convince them that killing said player is in the best interest of the ship. While it's unfortunate for the potential newbie, this game is a social one by design, and people who don't communicate can end up being a liability. If you have good reason to believe that the person is griefing or Mush through actions like these, then make your case to the crew, and file a report after it's over.

Make sure the crew understands that you are suggesting this in good faith, and that other attempts at communication have been tried first, as you described; the logs will reflect that. Give them some time to weigh in, if it's feasible. This is the same sort of process I'd use before killing a semi-inactive title holder, who logs in just enough to steal the title back, but doesn't act in the best interest of the ship. If nobody has any objections, and they're willing to spend the AP now in order to avoid prolong the damage done, then make the kill. A good time to file a report against the player is after they're dead, and you can see whether they were Mush. It wouldn't make sense to report a Mush for acting like a Mush, after all.

Following the above process also guarantees that it doesn't appear to be a random kill, which would be sanctionable if reported. And there's the side benefit that if they ARE a newbie, and they manage to read that you are discussing their execution...they might decide to start communicating. Of course, if that discussion instead causes them to attack someone, you can terminate them with extreme prejudice. Cover your bases.

ChumtinQ93: What does pathetic suicide mean? Does it just mean you suicided?

A93: Suicide is strictly against the rules, and that is the usual sanction one gets if they committed suicide. The game must be played to its natural conclusion. Note that setting yourself up to be killed can also be reported. As an example, sporing in a room with several people, plus a camera, and then going offline afterward. Mutating in a Dorm, and then not attacking anyone can be seen the same way.


goatQ95: it's not sanctionable if a player (non mush) kills 3 other players when the ship is inactive and non responsive and about to die (only 2 oxygens left) to find the mush right?
someone did that on previous ship and i thought it was funny but someone on crew told me that we should report. i didn't though
also Q96 how many people have to agree to kill a player for it not to be reported

A95: It can be sanctioned, IF one of the players killed felt it was a random kill. But every case is different.

A96: The number isn't an exact one, because every ship is so different. But the safest bet is to have all of the active players agreeing (or not voicing objections) AND the reason for the killing clearly laid out. If the need to kill that person is urgent, you can explain it immediately after, and hope they agree with you. But there's no way to guarantee that a report will be avoided.

At least if you have the reasons detailed, you will reduce the chances of getting sanctioned, in case it does get reported.

[7829214]

Q97: Does doing the thing as a mush cause a free transfer of spores to the uninfected human? As in, if I had already infected someone for today, would I still be able to infect? If so, does it use up a spore I have extracted, or is it free?

Q98: After infecting schrodinger, will I know it if it has scratched any crew member picking/cuddling it and infecting them?
On february 19, 2014
[7950824]

A97 Sort of to all your questions. You can directly spike someone 1x per day. But you can directly spike different people many times per day. If you have 1+ spores when you do it with a human, you lose 1 spore, that human gains 1 spore - this happens even if you already spiked that human today. Also, you can give 1 spore from do it, then spike the person the same day.

If you are alive and online, you will see a message in the mush channel whenever a human gets a spore - no matter why they get it. The message will tell you who caused the infection, how the spore was gained (trapped shelf, infected cat, whatever) and who set up the spore to be gained.
On february 19, 2014
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mchant ?

Actually, you can't directly spike more than one person a day. Only with the Infector skill can you spike twice a day (either the same person twice, or two different persons the same day).

Q105: I've done some superficial research, since I don't know really what I should be looking for, but it looks to me like you get more glory by returning to Sol (Return To Sol + 20 glory) than reaching Eden (Towards New Eden + 6 glory )
I've taken this two ships of mine, which reached Eden and Sol respectively.
http://mush.twinoid.com/theEnd/2485 (Eden)
http://mush.twinoid.com/theEnd/2285 (Sol)

Am I wrong? Am I right? If I'm right, it doesn't make sense since it's better to exhaust all projects, research, PILGRED, and planets, stay alive as long as possible, and finally return to Sol

On february 19, 2014
Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mchant ?

The system of glory is a little more complex for Eden, actually.

For reaching Sol, you get 20 glory + the glory of each research (you get 16 glory when the retro-fungal serum is completed and 16 again when you reach Sol). You also lose 10 glory for each mush still alive. The Mush get 16 glory.

For Eden, there are lots of different factors :
+1 for each person still alive (including the mush)
+8 if Schrdinger is alive, but -4 if he's dead or infected
+4 if both men and women are present on Eden
+1 for each type of alien plant on board
-1 for each crew member with an illness
-16 for each mush alive
+ the glory of all the research

Some characters also have specific glory (technicians and biologists have a bonus for reaching Eden, Jin Su and Chun too, Ian has another bonus for each type of plant).

The mush earn 32.

On february 22, 2014
[6826491]

A122: The list always contains one Alpha, even if that Alpha has already been killed. It might contain both Alphas, but this is never guaranteed.

This is why you wait to print the list until you've killed two Mush, or kill one and cure another. If the list can still be printed, then you have at least one Mush left...even if both Mush you dealt with were on the list. If you can't print the list, then you are free of Mush, at least for that moment. You'll still have to take precautions in case the cat is spored, and/or there may be trapped rooms for Chun to clear. There's also a possibility that a Mush Trap event on an expo will provide the last spore needed to convert someone.

On february 23, 2014
[6826491]
ZaphodBeeblbroxAs an example list: Soap, apron, extinguishers, blasters, mush sample, scooter, knife, grenade, hacker kit, medkit, drones, cameras, armor, bandages, expedition items... are a NO-NO.

If you announce that you have it, where you currently are, and that it's not going to be more than a few cycles before you can move it to where it needs to be...then reasonable exceptions can be made. After all, if you fail to make it available, then you've just negated any advantage you had from holding it. You just have to make sure you follow through with moving said item(s) at the time you said you would, or drop the item(s) so that someone else can do the moving. As a side benefit, doing this builds trust and communication.

Likewise, if you ask for permission to hold onto an item (say, if you're Terrence asking for the Scooter) and the crew agrees, an exception can be made there as well.

N_Faker

So may a Shooter skill Chao pick up a blaster before a full ship? Can Chun keep the Armor?

You never know how long it will take to fill a ship, and someone may see you were the last one to pick up or drop that item. If you don't want to make it seem that you were trying to hide the item, cover your bases and announce it, as I noted above. Q117 Is there any difference between death from inactivity and death from fatal depression being active(not "having a thing" though due to RP causes)(lots of dead people and no morale boost from Janice cause you're one)?
On february 24, 2014
[6826491]

A117: If someone dies due to Fatal Depression, OR if they are Quarantined by Neron, there is no morale loss to the rest of the human crew. If they die by any other means, including starvation, then the human crew loses one morale. Yes, even if the dead person is Mush.

Raluca has a skill that prevents morale loss when others die.

Aside from that, there are a limited number of ways to raise morale. For Janice, that's usually fruit, or Doing The Thing.

Q124 : What happens if you hyper freeze a coffee?
On february 25, 2014
[6826491]

A124: Frozen coffee and fruit will stop spoiling, but their current status will be maintained. So if something has a 90% chance to cause Food Poisoning when you freeze it, that status will still be there when you hyperdefrost it. Frozen food also COSTS one AP and one morale to consume, unless you hyperdefost it first. However, hyperdefrosting requires the use of the Microwave, and that comes with the same hazards of using the Microwave to cook rations...it can degrade or cut the link to Sol. If you no longer have the Microwave, it is impossible to hyperdefrost anything.

Q132b: How will it be handled if you pick up/drop the cat because of lag? Meaning: You want to drop the cat but because of lag it isn't registered and you try again and end up with more than 3-4 times picking up/dropping? In such a case it isn't considered a WANTED attempt or?
On february 26, 2014
[6826491]

A133: There's a very fine line between self-sacrifice and suicide, and the former is only permitted if doing so will save the ship from an imminent threat. (Or in the case of the Mush, if that death advances the Mush team's goals.) If the situation is desperate enough that the current commander must sacrifice themselves to save the ship, that may be permitted. But this has to be one of those things which is well discussed by the crew, and they must agree that it's to save the ship. After all, if one of them reports it as a suicide, then they obviously thought there was another option.

One player taking it upon themselves to use their last two AP to kill Aracks and let the ship avoid 2-3 asteroids, might also end up dying in the process, if Magnetic Net isn't online. But if the ship is out of shots in the turrets and the situation is just that desperate, it's either lose one pilot, or the whole ship. I can see that as being a self-sacrifice situation, rather than a Pathetic Suicide. The key word here is pathetic, however. If the ship could easily have been saved by a pilot who had the AP to take off and land, and that player was online...then that sacrifice may not have been necessary. Likewise, if out Pilot went out there, and just went offline without a word to the crew, that would fall under the Pathetic Suicide category.

As for Bait, it might not even work the way people think it does. The hunters may ignore the Bait ship and fire on Daedalus anyway.

In short, if it's to save the ship, and the crew agrees, however reluctantly...then they probably won't report it as a Pathetic Suicide.

Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mchant ?
ImpetA134 follow up question: Is it only early game difficulty that is affected by how much AP is spent, or does that affected the difficulty of mid and late game too?

It affects the whole game. In fact there are two things that affect the difficulty. The longer a ship lasts, the more difficult things get. That's why the command terminal says something about "Infinite space" and "Outer space" : it marks the two stages in the increase of difficulty (one on day 6, the other one on day 12). But it doesn't mean that the ship suddenly starts falling apart on day 6, it's more progressive. And it's also influenced by the crew's activity and the number of AP spent, though it's more complex than that. Apparently it's also based on the crew's capacity to face difficulties. Of course it doesn't mean that a ship where nothing happens will have a better chance of reaching day 10. If the crew isn't active at all, they won't last long.

Peanutz
Mais pourquoi est-il aussi mchant ?

It's not that simple. Otherwise, yes, it would be easy for a half inactive crew to break records, and of course that's not what is intended.

I'm not sure that it makes such a difference. We asked the dev to explain on the French forum a few months ago... and we're still trying to understand his answer. We also tried to do a casting ship where we did nothing... well, almost nothing, only the most vital actions (hunters, gardening, only 3 expeditions for oxygen, vital repairs, healing). We didn't finish PILGRED, we only had one non upgraded drone which did all the non urgent repairs, we didn't collect scrap, the comms manager didn't do anything, we only did a few basic research (pomade and lenses), built no blueprints. It was even strictly forbidden to convert AP into MP, and part of the crew went completely idle in the first week. We lasted 20 days, but the last days were a nightmare, with more than half the equipment broken, fires all the time, huge waves of hunters. And we only survived those last days because the crew was very active in the last days. In comparison, other ships where we didn't try to be "inactive" lasted much longer.

I think that it's only intended to help medium ships to cope with several inactive or not very active crew members. But in the end, a very good crew with very active crew members will have a much better chance of surviving. Coffee, Panic, Lethargy, Creative and other skills help (a lot) to cope better with the increase of difficulty. And spending AP on non vital things is not a waste at all. For example doing projects or utilitarian research means that you spend a lot of AP, but in the end, the ship will be better equiped to face hunters and other problems.
On february 26, 2014
npfan

Just speaking from experience here, the more inactives you have, the less likely you're going to face challenges the first few days. After about five days or so, difficulty, especially with hunters, is ramped up so the ship is not going to last long. In other words, if you have a very active crew, you will have a more natural progression in difficulty where a less active crew will see a more calm before the storm phenomenon. My guess is that if you happen to be on an active ship, you will see the true nature of the game, whereas a less active ship is set to be easy enough where the active people can potentially accomplish basic goals, like Mush hunting, repairing PILGRED, research Retro-Fungal Serum, and go to Sol.

I noticed recently that technicians can see which items can be damaged by a fire, because they can be reinforced. For example technicians can reinforce cameras, extinguishers, spacesuits, the hacker kit, the apron, all of which can be damaged by fires. The "reinforce" action isn't available for items that can be completely destroyed (usually consumables or perishable objects like blueprints, post-its, fruits, plants, books...), nor for items that can't be damaged or destroyed (like the wrench or the medikit).

On february 27, 2014
[6826491]
bootstrap666I was mainly asking because you said killing inactives was wrong period, i just wanted to make sure their were certain situations where it would be allowed,

There are three notable exceptions I can name offhand:

1. When the inactive (or barely active) player is directly interfering with ship operations, such as Paola's Logistics bonus, or as a title holder, they repeatedly log in to take their title back, but don't do anything to help the ship. This does not automatically permit killing a player the moment they become inactive, but it allows them some leeway to return to the game. Likewise, just being idle isn't enough of a reason to kill someone on its own.

2. When the inactive player has been inactive long enough that they should have starved, but didn't. This suggests you have very good reason to believe they're Mush.

3. If they are holding onto a critical item, such as the Apron and have been asked multiple times to drop it. If after a "reasonable" amount of time, they don't drop it, or they get the inactive status, killing the player is allowed. (I intentionally won't define how long a "reasonable" time is in this case, but you should err on the side of caution here.) This exception falls under the same concept as #1, above.

Killing inactive players should not be done randomly, or without evidence of wrongdoing. It can ultimately doom a ship if too much AP is wasted on killing inactives, not to mention the morale loss. Using these exceptions to justify maliciously killing multiple players can still lead to a sanction, if your crewmates think it was not in the best interest of the ship.

Q143 can other mush see which food are infected? for example mush A spored ration A and B, will mush B see that the food is spored?..

Q145 how does hiding work?.. will the person who hid the item be the only one to see it?.. or its a different case if the mush hides it and every mush can see it?..
On february 27, 2014
[7950824]

A143 yes, it will even form a separate stack for mush, a pile of infected food, a pile of non-infected, if there's more than one food item in the room.

A144 no, neither can see. Mush can trigger traps and receive no sign that they have done so (Chun setting off a trap is silent as well) but a human getting infected shows up on the mush channel.

A145 The hidden item is present on the shelf, but visible only to the person who hid it (mush or not). You can tell your partner what you've hidden and where, but they would still have to search to find it. Searching is 100% successful, however there's nothing to stop you from hiding many things in a room.

[6826491]

A146: If the ship is in good shape, and the crew wants to continue, then it's generally considered a Harmful Return if one person decides to return anyway. The person who will die in your example should either:

1. Try to convince the crew to return, OR if they don't succeed with that attempt...

2. Accept their fate, and not screw over the rest of the crew out of a longer voyage. A Harmful Return is almost always considered a Pathetic Suicide in which the rest of the crew is killed as well.

A147 You go to your page then to your settings and activate advanced mush. But it only works if you have more skills than skill slots otherwise it will pick the skills you have. So say that you have 4 levels in Gio and you are gold, then you wont be able to pick which of them you want, but if you are silver with level 4 Gioele you will be able to pick them yourself.
On february 27, 2014
[6826491]

A147:You need to have more skills than you have skill slots, if you want the choice of your available skills at the start of the ship. So that means if you're level 5 or 6 with a given character, you will always be able to choose that character's skills as a Gold player. Likewise, you need to be level 2 or higher for Bronze, or Level 3 or higher for Silver.

This might mean you need to play another character for a while, or just stick with the skills that are autopicked...a least until you can afford to buy the level 5 skill. (Even if you buy the level 5 skill while on a ship, you won't be able to assign it if you had skills 1-4 autopicked. That will wait until your next ship.)

And no, there is no way to turn this off. That's usually the next question people ask when they ask about autopicked skills.

On february 27, 2014
Secondary

A149 Jin Su, Paola, Roland, Hua, anyone that you have as pilot (or really anyone is good to have active, but these are best)
On february 27, 2014
[7950824]

A149: Any character can be useful in many ways if you are online a lot, but some have a primary job that ideally they can do at any time is needed: probably the most needed of those 'we need you now!' characters is Jin Su (or anyone who becomes a commander upon Jin's death or inactivity).

But because any character can fight fires, heal folks, read roomlogs, talk, think, and check stuff as needed... absolutely any character is highly useful in the hands of a highly active player.

Some jobs require a lot of patience to be very useful - astro and Pilot are probably the most demanding of those. Those jobs absolutely require you to have a lot of AP available, or don't even bother, since for example 4 AP in a pilot's hands will take off and land the fighter, but not actually fire any shots (or can fire 2 shots, but then you cannot land for at least 2 more cycles), and Scanning a planet but being unable to analyze it for many more cycles is a good way to throw away the AP used to scan it - because maybe the ship has to move before you even get the chance to analyze.

So I recommend you play what you love best, and because you are able to be highly active, you'll be giving your ship lots of extra active goodness because of your play. Player skills (activity maybe can be called a player skill) as much as character skills are what wins games for your team, very very often.

DampedWharfOk thankfully I thought to check here before confirming it. What happens once I report him? Do they for any reason ever remove someone from an ongoing ship?

I can't give specifics as to what happens after a report is submitted, and we will never discuss the results of individual reports publicly, for obvious reasons. We also won't inform a reporting player of what happened to the person(s) they reported. Though if you see "Quarantined by Neron" in their player history, that should be obvious, shouldn't it? As devilking noted, the judges won't look at a report until after the ship is over. This is in part because the punishment against a player must reflect their actions throughout the entirety of the ship, not just a single incident. Believe me when I say that people can earn a quarantine on their first sanction, and many of them have.

On march 1, 2014
[7950824]

A163 followup: Kersakof, the guy knew where those items were and made that list by spending his move points to walk around and check. Move points are a pretty valuable resource, you get them back slowly over time (and quickly through use of a few other limited resources), so that's very much not cheating, he earned the item locations!

Knowing where those things are is useful to both the humans and the mush; it's a bit of a double edged sword to list them, but it's extremely normal to do so, and I've found it a blessing both when playing human and when playing mush.

If I get onto a ship and it doesn't have an item thread, I create one (though I personally do not use astropad) and ask everyone to keep it current and report when they see from the roomlogs that someone else isn't keeping it current (aka, they took something 'sneakily'... might be because they are mush!)

[7950824]

So what's the best fix? In the moment, at that very second on that very ship, there isn't one that will 'work', if your goal is to change those people on that ship at that moment.

So... don't even look at that goal that you cannot hope to win.

Instead, strategize more broadly. If you think MMM ships are included in the problem as it personally affects you, then start talking about it on the MMM thread. On whatever ship you're on, talk about why to play neutral.

Use the existing threads, or send a PM to a mod asking them to make a reply to a thread about neutral play, so that you can provide a link to the concept on your ships.

Consider playing Finola, the character most capable of rushing research, and explain that the second mush are chosen the race is on, but you won't move from your bed until that moment.

Discuss the satisfaction of the race against the mush, done from the fairness of an equal starting line. How much more a fair win against the mush is worth than the alternative.

Conversely (or as well) discuss how dangerous and destructive some mush can be; how for you (or just some), if you become mush on a ship that's not playing fair, you're going to play for maximal destruction instantly, be that killing people, removing essential equipment from play, or whatever the max damage possible in the first few seconds possible is - if the humans want to encourage mush to possibly play the conversion game - they will voluntarily not start anti-mush research until the mush are in play...

I've recently read a lot of threads from people talking about how they prefer the mush they must play against to be sneaky and converting.

That's frankly silly - if the ship is rushing anti-mush from before there are mush especially. I can say that for me, there's no way I'd 'play nice' (which I consider conversion-focused play to be) as a mush on a ship that was rushing research from before there were mush. Now.... after there's mush. That's the game, race is on, and may the sneakiest and most determined players win

So talking about stuff like this, that's how I get the point across. Which tactics I use on any particular ship depends on the exact mix of personalities on the ship - but in each case (unless I'm doing it as a primary researcher) I don't expect to affect the current ship's outcome. Many exposures across many games, many lessons both harsh and gentle, that's how the message will get into peoples' heads.

[6826491]
JechtDoes it matter if people *approve* of it or not?.. Isn't your main goal is to prevent the humans in getting the cure?(going to sol or eden).. Isn't it like the *ghoul* version of mush?..

It does matter, because sometimes this move is done as a way to commit pathetic suicide; i.e. the player doesn't want to be Mush, and does it right after Mush selection. Even if it's advancing the team's goals, it's still screwing over their partner, who now has to deal with a full team of humans alone.

On the other hand, if you get caught through no intention of your own, it's a viable way to quickly do some damage before you die. The circumstances make the difference here, and it was specifically asked in terms of whether it's acceptable if one is caught. In this case, yes it is acceptable. It's also not the only option one can take.

The other reason this move is somewhat controversial (in terms of the spirit of the game) is that there's no finesse to it. Done 4-5 days in, as part of a well-planned murder spree? Fair game. Done just because one person didn't want to play Mush on day 1, and wanted an easy way out that isn't usually deemed a suicide? Not so fun for either team. It also ruins the thrill of the Mush hunt if the Mush off themselves in this sort of way. So, is it forbidden, per se? No. But should it be your first action as Mush? Expect to be reported by your partner if it is.

Secondary

[8151656]

Q189: If I know my way around the ship am i able to discard my tracker to free up a slot? or does it have other uses?
On march 3, 2014
[6826491]

A189: Depending upon the Projects your ship has completed, it can still be quite useful. Say you're the only Technician, and you're Terrence. One of the O2 tanks is broken. Your ship has the Anomaly Detector project completed, so you can see which of the O2 tanks it is, saving you some time and AP. You don't have to go searching for it, and you don't have to wait for someone to report its location.

Another example, but with something that's a guaranteed AP sink without the aid of Trackers: Fires. If you have the Fire Detector project, you'll see exactly where the fires are, and you can grab the nearest extinguisher, without having to have people wandering the ship...just to find that a fire was in a turret.

In both these cases, AP saved can then be spent dealing with the emergency, instead of being wasted in searching the ship. So the Tracker is still useful, even for experienced players. You might not always need it for the entire voyage, but even without either project, it can keep you from walking into a full Dorm, when there's an empty bed in the other one.
On march 3, 2014
[7924541]

A189: You can, Tracker is only good as a map and for showing the location of other players.

On march 5, 2014
N_Faker
Spazticus

A48: There's been some debate over this in the SDF, and the consensus we came to is this: The newly cured human CAN reveal who the other Mush are, and there are no rules being broken if they do reveal any other Mush. But they also aren't forced to do so by the rules.

There's an argument to be made about RP under those circumstances, and that's being taken into account here. It's up to the individual player to decide if they're going to reveal if there are other Mush, or to confirm that there are no other Mush. They can also choose to claim they don't remember, if they want to use that RP route.

However... That doesn't stop the other human players from killing the cured human, if that player refuses to name the other Mush. It's a very risky way to RP, obviously, but either choice (to reveal or not) conforms to the rules. And likewise, if the crew kills a player because they refused to reveal the Mush after being cured, that probably won't be sanctioned, either.

In short:

Can they reveal the other Mush? Yes, but they can also choose not to, and both options are valid.
Can you kill them for not revealing the other Mush? Yes, but you don't have to kill them if they refuse. (Consider that by curing them, you've regained an active player, in most circumstances...one who is now confirmed to be human. It would be a shame to have wasted the AP on the Serum, then choose to kill the person you just managed to save.)

Q224 Will a hunter attack once per 2 cycle or is it random?
On march 8, 2014
[7950824]

Moxrex's Q224: Most hunters attack once per cycle (the D1000 hunter supposedly attacks 3 times per cycle, and asteroids attack once only on a set cycle, either 5 or 6 cycles in the future from when you first see them).

However, hunters appear to be able to miss, and to crit, as well as to normally do a range of damage; so it's not possible to guess from the number of hunters facing the ship exactly how much damage will be taken any given cycle (and certain projects, like meridon scrambler can help reduce that further). I tend to guess that we'll average 2 damage per attacker per cycle.

However, hunters do not attack the cycle they appear (though Trax following you seem able to follow and shoot, and I believe following hunters actually do as well too). So when you get a wave, you have 2 cycles to react before you start taking damage.
